sen.j: 稲葉 正邦（いなば まさくに、1834年7月2日（天保5年5月26日 (旧暦)） - 1898年（明治31年）7月15日）は、江戸時代の大名・老中・京都所司代で、山城国淀藩12代目藩主であり、最後の藩主。
sen.e: Masakuni INABA (July 2, 1834 - July 15, 1898) was daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) in the Edo period as well as the twelfth and last lord of Yodo domain of the Yamashiro Province.

Masakuni INABA (July 2, 1834 - July 15, 1898) was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) in the Edo period as well as the twelfth and last lord of Yodo domain of the Yamashiro Province.

Masakuni INABA (July 2, 1834 - July 15, 1898) was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) in the Edo period as well as the twelfth and last lord of Yodo domain of the Yamashiro Province.

sen.j: 稲葉正成系稲葉氏宗家16代。
sen.e: He was the sixteenth soke (the head family) of the Inaba clan of Masanari INABA lineage.
He was the sixteenth soke (the head family) of the Inaba clan of Masanari INABA lineage.
He was the sixteenth soke (the head family) of the Inaba clan of Masanari INABA lineage.

sen.j: 陸奥国二本松藩主・丹羽長富の七男。
sen.e: He was the seventh son of Nagatomi NIWA, the lord of Nihonmatsu domain of the Mutsu Province.
He was the seventh son of Nagatomi NIWA, the lord of Nihonmatsu domain of the Mutsu Province.
He was the seventh son of Nagatomi NIWA, the lord of Nihonmatsu domain of the Mutsu Province.

sen.j: 後に稲葉正誼の元へ養子入りした。
sen.e: Later he was adopted as a child of Masayoshi INABA.
Later he was adopted as a child of Masayoshi INABA.
Later he was adopted as a child of Masayoshi INABA.

sen.j: 正室は酒井忠発の娘。
sen.e: His lawful wife was a daughter of Tadaaki SAKAI.
His lawful wife was a daughter of Tadaaki SAKAI.
His lawful wife was a daughter of Tadaaki SAKAI.

sen.j: 淀藩では譜代の城代家老田辺家が執政を取り仕切るならわしで、正邦の代においては田辺右京（後右京）が藩政を差配した。
sen.e: It was the custom in the Yodo Domain that hereditary Jodaigaro (deputy of a feudal lord) the Tanabe family managed the affairs and, in the generation of Masakuni, Ukyo TANABE (later Ukyo) managed domain duties.
sen.cmt: Webでは、「田辺権大夫（後右京）」となっていましたが、原文通りに訳出しました。
sen.e: It was the custom in the Yodo Domain that hereditary Jodaigaro (deputy of a feudal lord) the Tanabe family managed the affairs and, in the generation of Masakuni, Ukyo TANABE (later Ukyo) managed domain duties.

It was the custom in the Yodo Domain that hereditary Jodaigaro (deputy of a feudal lord) the Tanabe family managed the affairs and, in the generation of Masakuni, Ukyo TANABE (later Ukyo) managed domain duties.

sen.j: 田辺氏と正邦とは意見を違えることが多かったらしい。
sen.e: The Tanabe clan and Masakuni seemed often to differ with one another.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Tanabe clan and Masakuni seemed often to differ with one another.
The Tanabe clan and Masakuni seemed often to differ with one another.

sen.j: 急進・改革を唱える正邦に対して田辺家は穏健派であったらしい。
sen.e: It seemed that the Tanabe family was moderate while Masakuni advanced radical behavior and reform.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It seemed that the Tanabe family was moderate while Masakuni advocated radical behavior and reform.
It seemed that the Tanabe family was moderate while Masakuni advocated radical behavior and reform.

sen.j: 日常の藩主の執務に対して田辺氏が随行しないこともあったと、当該期史料に残る。
sen.e: According to the historical materials of the period, it was described that the Tanabe clan did not sometimes accompany their lord for its daily work.
According to the historical materials of the period, it was described that the Tanabe clan did not sometimes accompany their lord for its daily work.
According to the historical materials of the period, it was described that the Tanabe clan did not sometimes accompany their lord for its daily work.

sen.j: 稲葉家は西国に睨みを利かせる畿内随一の藩であることから、正邦も当初から江戸幕府内での昇進が早かった。
sen.e: Because the Inaba family was the best domain in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) having great influence over Saigoku (western part of Japan (esp. Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)), Masakuni was also quickly promoted in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from the beginning.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because the Inaba family was the most powerful domain in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) having great influence over Saigoku (western part of Japan (especially Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)), Masakuni was also quickly promoted in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from the beginning.

Because the Inaba family was the most powerful domain in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) having great influence over Saigoku (western part of Japan (especially Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)), Masakuni was also quickly promoted in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from the beginning.

sen.j: 会津藩・桑名藩と薩摩藩が同盟を結んだ頃から京都所司代となり、京都の政務を一任されていた。
sen.e: When the Aizu Domain and the Kuwana Domain formed an alliance with the Satsuma Domain, he became Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) and government affairs in Kyoto were left to his discretion.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When the Aizu Domain and the Kuwana Domain formed an alliance with the Satsuma Domain, he became Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) and government affairs in Kyoto were left to his discretion.
When the Aizu Domain and the Kuwana Domain formed an alliance with the Satsuma Domain, he became Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) and government affairs in Kyoto were left to his discretion.

sen.j: 後、老中、さらには政事総裁として、もっぱら江戸藩邸での活動に終始する。
sen.e: Later, he focused entirely on his activities in edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) as roju and even president of political affairs.
Later, he focused entirely on his activities in edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) as roju and even president of political affairs.
Later, he focused entirely on his activities in edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) as roju and even president of political affairs.

sen.j: 幕府での位置づけが高まることから、第一次・第二次長州征伐への淀藩士派兵を決定するが、田辺権大夫の強硬な反対によって断念するという一幕があった。
sen.e: There was an event that he decided to dispatch troops of feudal retainers of Yodo Domain to the First and Second Conquests of Choshu because it would allow to improve his position in the bakufu, but he gave it up due to strong opposition from Gon no daibu TANABE.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There was an event that he decided to dispatch troops of feudal retainers of Yodo Domain to the First and Second Conquests of Choshu because it would allow to improve his position in the bakufu, but he gave it up due to strong opposition from Gon no daibu TANABE.

There was an event that he decided to dispatch troops of feudal retainers of Yodo Domain to the First and Second Conquests of Choshu because it would allow to improve his position in the bakufu, but he gave it up due to strong opposition from Gon no daibu TANABE.

sen.j: 佐幕急進派の藩主と穏健派の藩首脳部の対立は顕在化していったらしい。
sen.e: It seemed that a conflict between the lord of the domain as radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate and the chief executives of the domain as moderates started to become obvious.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It seemed that a conflict between the lord of the domain as radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate and the chief executives of the domain as moderates started to become obvious.
It seemed that a conflict between the lord of the domain as radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate and the chief executives of the domain as moderates started to become obvious.

sen.j: 老中を抱える藩として鳥羽・伏見の戦いには淀城より出兵、数名の戦死者を記録するも、藩首脳部と京都朝廷との密約成立により朝廷に恭順。
sen.e: As the domain with roju, troops were dispatched from the Yodo-jo Castle to the Battle of Toba-Fushimi and several persons were recorded as being killed in action, but the domain gave obedience to the Imperial Court due to the conclusion of a secret agreement between the chief executives of the domain and the Imperial Court in Kyoto.

As the domain with roju, troops were dispatched from the Yodo-jo Castle to the Battle of Toba-Fushimi and several persons were recorded as being killed in action, but the domain gave obedience to the Imperial Court due to the conclusion of a secret agreement between the chief executives of the domain and the Imperial Court in Kyoto.

As the domain with roju, troops were dispatched from the Yodo-jo Castle to the Battle of Toba-Fushimi and several persons were recorded as being killed in action, but the domain gave obedience to the Imperial Court due to the conclusion of a secret agreement between the chief executives of the domain and the Imperial Court in Kyoto.

sen.j: このとき、江戸で将軍の留守政権の首脳として活動していた正邦は、自らの藩が自らの決定無くして幕府に反旗を翻すという事態に遭遇、結局淀へ退去することとなる。
sen.e: At that time, Masakuni, who has been working in Edo as the leader of government where the Shogun was absent, faced a situation where his domain rebelled against the bakufu without his decision and finally he left to Yodo.

At that time, Masakuni, who has been working in Edo as the leader of government where the Shogun was absent, faced a situation where his domain rebelled against the bakufu without his decision and finally he left to Yodo.

At that time, Masakuni, who has been working in Edo as the leader of government where the Shogun was absent, faced a situation where his domain rebelled against the bakufu without his decision and finally he left to Yodo.

sen.j: 稲葉家はその後も新政府に対する恭順の姿勢を貫き、正邦ら佐幕急進派が分裂することもなかった。
sen.e: Thereafter, the Inaba family continued to maintain their allegiance to new government, and radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate including Masakuni did not split up.
Thereafter, the Inaba family continued to maintain their allegiance to new government, and radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate including Masakuni did not split up.
Thereafter, the Inaba family continued to maintain their allegiance to new government, and radicals supporting Tokugawa shogunate including Masakuni did not split up.

sen.j: 版籍奉還により淀藩知事となり、廃藩置県によりその座を退く。
sen.e: He became the governor of Yodo Domain due to Hanseki-hokan (the return of the land and people from the feudal lords to the Emperor) and retired from the post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

He became the governor of Yodo Domain due to Hanseki-hokan (the return of the land and people from the feudal lords to the Emperor) and retired from the post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

He became the governor of Yodo Domain due to Hanseki-hokan (the return of the land and people from the feudal lords to the Emperor) and retired from the post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

sen.j: 墓所は東京都港区 (東京都)南青山の青山霊園。
sen.e: His graveyard was in Aoyama Cemetery at Minami Aoyama, Minato Ward, Tokyo.
His graveyard was in Aoyama Cemetery at Minami Aoyama, Minato Ward, Tokyo.
His graveyard was in Aoyama Cemetery at Minami Aoyama, Minato Ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 後は養子の稲葉正縄が継いだ。
sen.e: He was succeeded by his adopted son Masanawa INABA.
He was succeeded by his adopted son Masanawa INABA.
He was succeeded by his adopted son Masanawa INABA.

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: ※日付＝旧暦
sen.e: * Date = in the lunar calendar
* Date = in the lunar calendar
* Date = in the lunar calendar

sen.j: 1848年（嘉永元年）12月、家督相続。
sen.e: In December 1848, he took over as the head of the family.
In December 1848, he took over as the head of the family.
In December 1848, he took over as the head of the family.

sen.j: 年月日不詳、従五位下長門守に叙任。
sen.e: Year and date unknown, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no kami (deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).
Year and date unknown, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no kami (deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).
Year and date unknown, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no kami (deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).

sen.j: 1854年（安政元年）10月9日、奏者番就任。
sen.e: In October 9, 1854, he assumed the post of sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
On October 9, 1854, he assumed the post of sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
On October 9, 1854, he assumed the post of sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).

sen.j: 以前は雁之間詰。
sen.e: He was previously Karinomatsume (feudal lord that Karino-ma room in Edo-jo castle was set as his station).
His previous post was Karinomatsume (feudal lord that Karino-ma room in Edo-jo castle was set as his station).
sen.cmt: He was previously → His previous post was
sen.e: His previous post was Karinomatsume (feudal lord that Karino-ma room in Edo-jo castle was set as his station).

sen.j: 1863年（文久3年）6月11日、京都所司代に異動。
sen.e: In June 11, 1863, he was moved to work as Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).
On June 11, 1863, he was moved to work as Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).
On June 11, 1863, he was moved to work as Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).

sen.j: 年月日不詳、従四位下に昇叙し、侍従兼任。
sen.e: Year and date unknown, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and also served as jiju (chamberlain).
Year and date unknown, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and also served as jiju (chamberlain).
Year and date unknown, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and also served as jiju (chamberlain).

sen.j: 1864年（元治元年）4月11日、老中に異動。
sen.e: In April 11, 1864, he was moved to work as roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate).
On April 11, 1864, he was moved to work as roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate).
On April 11, 1864, he was moved to work as roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate).

sen.j: 月日不詳、美濃守に遷任。
sen.e: Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).
Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).
Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).

sen.j: 侍従如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).

sen.j: 10月13日、民部大輔に転任。
sen.e: On October 13, he was transferred to Minbu no taifu (Commissioner of Civil Affairs, the second-ranking officer, fifth rank, lower grade in the Bureau of Civil Affairs).
On October 13, he was transferred to Minbu no taifu (Commissioner of Civil Affairs, the second-ranking officer, fifth rank, lower grade in the Bureau of Civil Affairs).
On October 13, he was transferred to Minbu no taifu (Commissioner of Civil Affairs, the second-ranking officer, fifth rank, lower grade in the Bureau of Civil Affairs).

sen.j: 侍従如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).

sen.j: 1865年（元治2年）4月11日、老中辞任。
sen.e: In April 11, 1865, he resigned as roju.
On April 11, 1865, he resigned as roju.
On April 11, 1865, he resigned as roju.

sen.j: 雁之間詰となる。
sen.e: He became Karinomatsume.
He became Karinomatsume.
He became Karinomatsume.

sen.j: 1866年（慶応2年）4月13日、老中再任。
sen.e: In April 13, 1866, he was reappointed to his former position as roju.
On April 13, 1866, he was reappointed to his former position as roju.
On April 13, 1866, he was reappointed to his former position as roju.

sen.j: 月日不詳、美濃守に遷任。
sen.e: Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).
Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).
Date unknown, he was transferred to Mino no kami (governor of Mino Province).

sen.j: 侍従如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).
He remained in the position of jiju (chamberlain).

sen.j: 10月11日、外国御用取扱兼務。
sen.e: On October 11, as an additional post, he was in charge of diplomacy.
On October 11, as an additional post, he was in charge of diplomacy.
On October 11, as an additional post, he was in charge of diplomacy.

sen.j: 1867年（慶応3年）5月6日、外国御用取扱を止め、内国事務総裁兼務。
sen.e: In May 6, 1867, he stopped working for diplomacy and doubled as naikoku jimu sosai (the director general of Domestic Affairs Office).
On May 6, 1867, he stopped working for diplomacy and doubled as naikoku jimu sosai (the director general of Domestic Affairs Office).
On May 6, 1867, he stopped working for diplomacy and doubled as naikoku jimu sosai (the director general of Domestic Affairs Office).

sen.j: 1868年（慶応4年）1月23日、内国事務総裁兼務御役御免。
sen.e: In January 23, 1868, he retired from the position of naikoku jimu sosai.
On January 23, 1868, he retired from the position of naikoku jimu sosai.
On January 23, 1868, he retired from the position of naikoku jimu sosai.

sen.j: 2月21日、老中御役御免。
sen.e: On February 21, he retired from roju.
On February 21, he retired from roju.
On February 21, he retired from roju.

sen.j: 1874年（明治7年）11月、東京都港区芝大門鎮座の芝大神宮祠官就任。
sen.e: In November 1874, he assumed the post of priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine enshrined at Shiba-Daimon, Minato ward, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 用語集では芝大門はShibaotoとなっていましたが、読み方は「しばだいもん」が正しいと思われますので、Shiba-Daimonと訳出しました。参考：http://www.post.japanpost.jp/cgi-zip/zipcode.php?pref=13&city=1131030&id=46638
sen.e: In November 1874, he assumed the post of priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine enshrined at Shiba-Daimon, Minato ward, Tokyo.
In November 1874, he assumed the post of priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine enshrined at Shiba-Daimon, Minato ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 1876年（明治9年）1月、神道大教院事務局第三部管長兼務。
sen.e: In January 1876, he doubled as chief abbot of third section in Shinto Daikyoin (Great Teaching Institute of Shinto) Jimukyoku (bureau).
In January 1876, he doubled as chief abbot of third section in Shinto Daikyoin (Great Teaching Institute of Shinto) Jimukyoku (bureau).
In January 1876, he doubled as chief abbot of third section in Shinto Daikyoin (Great Teaching Institute of Shinto) Jimukyoku (bureau).

sen.j: 1878年（明治11年）5月、芝大神宮祠官辞任。
sen.e: In May 1878, he resigned as priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine.
In May 1878, he resigned as priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine.
In May 1878, he resigned as priest of Shiba-daijingu Shrine.

sen.j: 1884年（明治17年）7月8日、子爵を授爵。
sen.e: In July 8, 1884, he was created viscount.
On July 8, 1884, he was created viscount.
On July 8, 1884, he was created viscount.

sen.j: 1885年（明治18年）、神道事務局の初代管長就任。
sen.e: In 1885, he assumed the post of the first chief abbot of Shinto Jimukyoku (secretariat of Shinto).
In 1885, he assumed the post of the first chief abbot of Shinto Jimukyoku (secretariat of Shinto).
In 1885, he assumed the post of the first chief abbot of Shinto Jimukyoku (secretariat of Shinto).

sen.j: 1886年（明治19年）、神道事務局より神道本局に改組し、引き続き管長。
sen.e: In 1886, Shinto Jimukyoku was reorganized into Shinto Honkyoku and he continued to serve as the chief abbot.
In 1886, Shinto Jimukyoku was reorganized into Shinto Honkyoku (home office) and he continued to serve as the chief abbot.
